How long did you have to wait the last time you went to see your doctor was it longer than the time you actually spent with the physician what is the only person you saw when you went to the doctor's office was the doctor
There is a growing trend micro medical practices were doctors do it all from taking your blood pressure to building your insurance Dr crispy odd has a micro practice in Portland, Oregon the first thing you notice when you come into her office is that there's really no waiting room
There's an exam room and a space that looks a lot like a living room where crispy meets with her patients before and after their medical exam
She's an internist and pediatrician her patients call her doctor Chrissy she says the in formality is intentional
Part of the philosophy behind having more accessible approach to medicine is being more I'm more human more ... more accessible I'm In every way
When you graduated from medical school what did you envision in terms of of a job I envisioned
And accepted a job in a multi specialty care center where I worked with probably over a hundred other physicians and had a very busy day of twenty plus patients each day had a panel of close to two thousand patients very quickly
And that's a that's what many primary care doctors expect coming out is just sort of to jump on the treadmill and start running as fast as possible
During the second year of my employment my first job after residency I met a woman named Pamela liable who was a family physician in Eugene Oregon
And Pamela introduced me to this concept of micro practice and it immediately blew my mind and it was three months later that I opened the practice how was the transition how did that occur [noise] it was a phonetic
Time so contacting insurance companies requesting contract reviewing the contract filling them and with all of my degrees and board certifications and malpractice insurance data
And all of that so it's just a lot of paperwork
Yeah fit normally physicians don't ever see because all they do assigned the bottom line them and a a very helpful administrative person has gathered all of that for them it
Seems like a short amount of time given all the stuff that you'd have to set up and you had to find a location and you know I even have to hire anybody but um but you didn't have to figure out how you were going to do all the all the jobs so they
Have in mind that location designed the space by medical equipment
The office was a a fell into place I found it on Craig's list and it's half a mile from my home and it's in a quiet corner northeast Portland it's just I I Love my locations awesome
How does your colleagues react when you told them I'm leaving this practice and I'm going to start my own practice in this sort of unusual way it's it's not spoken in medical training but there's this sort of
Um subliminal
Curriculum that tells you you could never do this on your own it's way too complex and
What I felt and what I've verified is that it doesn't have to be I see fewer patients per day but for me it makes my practice more sustainable it keeps me in love with practicing medicine and keeps me engaged with my patients instead of looking past them or
Feeling rushed to complete a ten minute appointment so what is it typical day like for you I see my first patient at ten has a two hour administrative break from twelve to to one of those days per week I meet with my ministry of assistant who is relatively new addition and who works remotely
Average five to seven patients each day can you can you walk me through sort of a typical appointment like it it starts
Not with the waiting room right there's no waiting room because there's pretty much no waiting unless somebody arrived early to their appointment so I only see one patient or family in the office at a time and we sit down in a in an area that looks a lot like a living room they're sitting on a sofa I'm sitting in a chair
And we might have tea I'm available for us to share while we're chatting about the reason for their visit
A after we've talked for a little bit we go into the examination room where it performed physical exam and then we return to the sitting area and I write a prescription or order lab results or discuss the planned whatever it might be with them
And so did you start out doing all of this by yourself you said now you've got an administrative person when you start out doing absolutely everything I started out doing absolutely everything with the exception of book keeping my partner does the bookkeeping for the business
And that also gave us an opportunity to have a small group which allowed us to purchase our own health insurance as a group rather than an as individuals and so what was it like the first year what did you think about going back
I never thought about going back I really enjoyed this particular style of medicine if someone calls me in the middle of the night with
A health related emergency I Know who they are now I have a sense of their medical history it's not one of two thousand it's one of
Four hundred something instead which is much more manageable
How long are you spending with each of your patients and new patient visit is usually sixty to Ninety minutes
I'm a follow up visits is thirty to forty five minutes a well child check is forty five to sixty minutes in previous practices and in most practices it's a luxury to spend twenty minutes at a well child check
And I understand from your website that you are not taking any new patients I I Do have the waitlist it's about six to nine months on average right now I Can't
See a lot of new people each week because that would interrupt the availability of same day an urgent need appointments for my existing patients but with this sort of moderated growth it's working really well do you sometimes wish that you could see more people
I'm pretty happy with the pace of things as it is it's certainly not get rich quick schemes [laughter] I'm In fact I Would caution many physicians who might be ... that you will take a significant pay cut so who covers for you when you go on vacation
I have a few colleagues in the area and the five of us sort of
Help each other out when we go on vacation in fact I was on call for Dr Hudson last week it's obvious how this is better for patients um tell me a little bit more about how it's better for you well I get to sleep in [laughter]
That's a really wonderful part of my quality of life right now is that they don't have to get up at five thirty in the morning to be
At the office at seven to start seeing as many patients as possible all day long the hours are a blessing to me and again the intimacy with my patients and how well I get to know these families
Really makes my job a pleasure and sustains my interest in love of medicine are there are there downsides for you I think that the downside potentially is isolation that I don't have a colleague in the office next door
To say hey what do you think about this case or can you can look at this raft with me what do you think about this which I Do miss you said that that that this is kind of reflective of your personality is that is that on your end I've been told that I started saying that I wanted to do it all by myself
Around age two and never stops [laughter]
Very well or oh ooh
That's Dr Chris he or she has a micro practice in Portland, Oregon we have some links to more information about the unique approach to Madison on our website destination the I

And noticed that a lot of times in in our reporting we will mention that someone is black or Latino or Asian or Native American if they are but white people we we we don't we that's just a person
You know we said Joe ... is a plumber who lives in this town in Ohio now if if that person's black it's for one thing it's very likely going to be part of the story that they are black
But we don't do that with white people and that's a this is one of the things that people who think more deeply about whiteness point out is that they call it unmarked this
Or that whiteness is sort of treated as the default it's the that you're just a person if you're white and then and and and it's non white people who have race
So John we'll flip that on ... on its head
The next ten episodes obscene on radio will be all about the white race and white ... no ...
It's a critical look at white dominated society with stories about the origins of race a town that has forgotten the racial cleansing that took place there and northern innocence the idea among whites in the northern us that the south has more to answer for
I Am really looking forward to the whole series again it's called seeing white it's part of the podcast scene on radio and seen by the way is spelled F. C. E. N. E.
